title: How to Make Horehound Tea

steps.headline: Begin with a saucepan or metal teapot with cool water to brew horehound tea.
steps.description: Place the water on high heat and bring the water to a full boil.

steps.headline: Pour a small amount of the hot water in an enamel, ceramic, or other non-metal but not plastic, heat-proof container, as the hot water will warm the pot.
steps.description: A non-metal container is preferred, as a metal container can compromise the purity of the horehound tea as will plastic. Swish the hot water in the container, then pour the water down the sink.

steps.headline: Place fresh horehound leaves in the container, then pour the boiling water over the leaves.
steps.description: Cover and steep. Horehound has essential oils that will evaporate with the steam, so steeping should be done while covered tightly. You can use a saucer, some tea cups come with a decorative cover for this purpose. Use 2 tablespoons of fresh horehound leaves for each cup of boiling water. Traditionally, one extra tablespoon of fresh leaves are added "for the pot." If you are making tea with dried horehound, use one tablespoon for each cup of boiling water, plus one tablespoon "for the pot."

steps.headline: Pour the boiling water over the horehound leaves, then allow them to steep for at least five minutes.
steps.description: Check the tea often, as the steeping time will depend on if you prefer your horehound tea weak or strong.

steps.headline: Strain the horehound tea through a fine mesh strainer or a piece of clean cheesecloth when the tea reaches the desired strength.
steps.description: Garnish the horehound tea with honey, a sprig of peppermint, a small amount of fresh ginger or a lemon slice. A teaspoon of anise seed will provide a licorice flavor to your horehound tea.

Pour a small amount of the hot water in an enamel, ceramic, or other non-metal but not plastic, heat-proof container, as the hot water will warm the pot. A non-metal container is preferred, as a metal container can compromise the purity of the horehound tea as will plastic. Swish the hot water in the container, then pour the water down the sink. Place fresh horehound leaves in the container, then pour the boiling water over the leaves. Cover and steep. Horehound has essential oils that will evaporate with the steam, so steeping should be done while covered tightly. You can use a saucer, some tea cups come with a decorative cover for this purpose. Use 2 tablespoons of fresh horehound leaves for each cup of boiling water. Traditionally, one extra tablespoon of fresh leaves are added "for the pot." If you are making tea with dried horehound, use one tablespoon for each cup of boiling water, plus one tablespoon "for the pot." Pour the boiling water over the horehound leaves, then allow them to steep for at least five minutes. Check the tea often, as the steeping time will depend on if you prefer your horehound tea weak or strong. Strain the horehound tea through a fine mesh strainer or a piece of clean cheesecloth when the tea reaches the desired strength. Garnish the horehound tea with honey, a sprig of peppermint, a small amount of fresh ginger or a lemon slice. A teaspoon of anise seed will provide a licorice flavor to your horehound tea.
